citation.article-title: Reclassification of Brevibacterium imperiale (Steinhaus) and Corynebacterium laevaniformans (Dias and Bhat) in a redefined genus Microbacterium (Orla-Jensen) as Microbacterium imperiale comb. nov. and Microbacterium laevaniformans nom. rev.; comb. nov.

p.s: Description of Microbacterium laevaniformans nom. rev.; comb. nov.

This description is based on the literature description of "Corynebacterium laevaniformans" (Dias and Bhat); Dias and Bhat, 1962, 1964; Bousfield, 1972; Schleifer and Kandler, 1972; Keddie and Cure, 1978; Collins and Jones, 1981; Döpfer et al., 1982; the present work.
Good growth on solid media in air; colonies are 1 to 3 mm diam., circular, low convex, entire margin, opaque and moist.
Yellow pigment produced.
In young cultures, small, slender rods formed.
Many cells are arranged at an angle to give V-formations; primary branching uncommon.
In older cultures rods become shorter.
Rods are Gram-positive, non-acid fast, non-motile; endospores are not formed.
Optimum growth temperature ca. 30°C.
Good aerobic growth; weak anaerobic growth.
Acid (but no gas) produced from glucose, fructose, galactose, sucrose, mannose, trehalose, raffinose, lactose, maltose, cellobiose, dextrin, sorbitol, mannitol, glycerol and glycogen.
No acid produced from N-acctylglucosamine, xylose, arabinose, inulin, inositol, salicin, arbutin, sorbose, dulcitol, ribose, melibiose and rhamnose. β-galactosidase negative.
Catalase positive.
Cellulose and hippurate not hydrolysed.
Starch and gelatin hydrolysed.
Arginine utilized.
Urease negative.
H2S produced.
Nitrate not reduced.
Nutritionally exacting: biotin, thiamine and pantothenic acid required for growth (Dias and Bhat, 1964).
Survive heating at 60°C for
30 min.
Cell wall peptidoglycan type B1α: (Schleifer and Kandler, 1972).
Galactose is the main cell wall sugar (Keddie and Cure, 1978).
Mycolic acids are not present.
Non-hydroxylated long-chain fatty acids consist of predominantly anteiso- and iso- methyl branched chain acids; straight-chain saturated and monounsaturated acids present in only small amounts.
Major fatty acids are anteiso-C15 and anteiso-C17;.
Major menaquinones consist of unsaturated MK-11 and MK-12.
Polar lipids comprise diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylglycerol and dimannosyldiacylglycerol; unknown monoglycosyldiacylglycerol sometimes present.
DNA base composition is 70 to 73.7 mol % G + C.
Habitat: activated sludge.
The type strain is NCIB 9659.
